definitions: The main contractile protein of the thin filament that binds with myosin to generate force.
A thin-filament protein that provides the track for myosin cross-bridge attachment.
The primary protein of thin myofilaments; interacts with myosin heads during contraction.
A myofibrillar protein anchored to Z-lines that slides past myosin during shortening.
A structural/contractile protein whose exposed binding sites enable cross-bridge cycling.
The thin-filament protein that, when unblocked by tropomyosin, permits myosin binding.
A key sarcomere protein that contributes to force when myosin pulls it toward the M-line.
A major thin-filament component responsible for transmitting contractile force through the sarcomere.
An anaerobic energy system that resynthesizes ATP primarily from phosphocreatine without lactate formation.
The immediate energy pathway supplying rapid ATP via stored ATP and PCr during very short, high-power work.
A non-oxidative system using PCr to buffer ATP demand, producing no lactate as an end-product.
The short-duration energy system dominated by ATP and phosphocreatine breakdown and resynthesis.
An anaerobic pathway that supports maximal efforts for ~0–10 seconds through PCr-driven ATP resynthesis.
The high-power system where creatine kinase transfers phosphate from PCr to ADP to rebuild ATP.
A rapid energy source for sprints/jumps that relies on stored high-energy phosphates rather than glycolysis.
The ATP–phosphocreatine pathway characterized by fast ATP availability and minimal metabolic byproducts.
An anaerobic energy system that rapidly produces ATP via glycolysis with lactate accumulation.
The non-oxidative pathway that breaks down carbohydrate to generate ATP and forms lactate and H+.
A high-rate glycolytic energy system supporting hard efforts typically ~10–120 seconds.
The anaerobic pathway where glucose/glycogen is metabolized to pyruvate and then lactate under high demand.
A carbohydrate-based ATP system that supplies energy quickly when oxygen delivery cannot meet demand.
The energy system associated with rising blood lactate and metabolic acidosis during intense exercise.
A rapid ATP-producing pathway that trades efficiency for speed, producing lactate as a product of high flux.
The glycolysis-dominant system that powers sustained high-intensity bouts and results in lactate formation.
Training performed at intensities that rely heavily on phosphagen and/or glycolytic energy systems.
Exercise that emphasizes ATP production without primary dependence on oxygen-driven metabolism.
High-intensity work designed to stress the phosphagen and glycolytic pathways.
Training characterized by hard efforts where energy demand outpaces aerobic ATP supply.
Work bouts that preferentially develop power/speed capacity and lactate tolerance/production systems.
Exercise using short-duration, high-intensity intervals to target non-oxidative metabolism.
Training that develops performance in activities requiring rapid ATP resynthesis without sustained oxygen use.
Workouts that stress anaerobic energy contributions through intensity, not necessarily total duration.
A phenomenon where maximal bilateral force is less than the summed force of each limb tested unilaterally.
Reduced total force output when both limbs contract together compared with unilateral contractions added.
A neural phenomenon in which bilateral activation does not fully match unilateral motor drive.
A performance effect where two-limb output is lower than expected from single-limb capabilities.
A motor-control limitation sometimes seen in bilateral strength tasks versus unilateral strength tests.
A situation where simultaneous limb contraction yields less combined force than unilateral totals.
A bilateral force shortfall often attributed to neural inhibition or incomplete motor unit activation.
A finding where left + right (separately) > both together, despite similar mechanics.
A phenomenon where maximal bilateral force exceeds what would be predicted from unilateral force measures.
Enhanced force output when both limbs act together compared with unilateral performance.
A neural effect where bilateral contraction increases motor drive beyond unilateral levels.
A performance boost where two-limb output is greater than the sum-based expectation from single-limb tests.
Greater strength expression during simultaneous limb contraction relative to unilateral output benchmarks.
A condition where bilateral tasks show amplified force production compared with unilateral comparisons.
An effect suggesting improved coordination or neural activation when limbs work together.
A scenario where both together outperforms what unilateral testing would predict.
The composite material of bone made of organic proteins and inorganic minerals.
Bone’s structural framework consisting mainly of collagen fibers plus mineral crystals.
The extracellular scaffold that provides bone with both toughness and hardness.
The organic (osteoid) and inorganic (mineral) components that give bone its properties.
A collagen-rich foundation mineralized by hydroxyapatite to create rigid bone tissue.
The structural substance of bone that supports load and resists deformation.
Bone tissue material formed from collagen, ground substance, and deposited mineral salts.
The combined protein-and-mineral architecture responsible for bone strength and structure.
A measure of mineral content in bone per unit area (or volume) used as an index of bone strength.
An indicator of how much mineral is packed into bone, often linked to fracture risk.
A clinical metric reflecting bone mass and mineralization.
A value used to assess bone health, commonly measured by DXA scanning.
The density of mineral in bone tissue associated with stiffness and resistance to fracture.
A proxy measure for bone strength based on mineral content relative to size.
A bone-quality indicator where lower values generally imply higher osteoporosis risk.
A measurement representing mineralized bone mass normalized to an area/volume.
A structural protein that provides tensile strength to connective tissues.
The primary fibrous protein in tendons, ligaments, and fascia that resists stretching.
A major extracellular matrix protein forming strong, rope-like fibers.
A protein scaffold that helps tissues withstand pulling forces.
The dominant protein in many connective tissues, critical for stiffness and integrity.
A connective tissue protein that forms fibers supporting load transmission.
A structural protein whose cross-links influence tissue rigidity.
The main protein framework that supports tissues subjected to tension.
Dense outer bone that provides high strength and structural support.
The compact, rigid bone layer forming the outer shell of most bones.
Bone tissue optimized to resist bending and torsion through dense architecture.
The thick outer bone material with relatively low porosity.
The strong outer bone region that bears most mechanical load.
Compact bone that contributes substantially to bone stiffness and strength.
The dense bone layer surrounding the medullary cavity and trabecular region.
A hard, compact tissue that forms the bone cortex and provides load-bearing capacity.
Strength gains in an untrained limb following unilateral training of the opposite limb.
A neural carryover where training one side improves strength on the other side.
The contralateral strength transfer effect from unilateral exercise.
An adaptation where unilateral training enhances motor output in the nontrained limb.
A phenomenon often attributed to central nervous system adaptations rather than local muscle changes.
A strength transfer effect useful during injury rehabilitation when one limb cannot be trained directly.
Unilateral training-induced improvements in the opposite limb’s force capacity.
A neural adaptation where practice/strength on one side partially generalizes to the contralateral side.
Chemical bonds between collagen fibers that increase tissue stiffness.
The formation of links between collagen molecules that strengthens connective tissue.
A process that reduces tissue compliance by binding collagen structures together.
A structural change that increases rigidity and load transfer capacity of connective tissue.
Bonding between collagen fibrils that influences tendon and ligament mechanical properties.
A mechanism by which connective tissue becomes less deformable under load.
A tissue-stiffening process driven by chemical link formation within collagen networks.
Increased collagen-to-collagen bonding that raises tensile strength and stiffness.
The partial or complete loss of training adaptations due to reduced or absent training.
A decline in performance and physiological capacity after training stops or drops markedly.
Reversal of training-induced gains when stimulus is insufficient.
Loss of fitness characteristics such as strength, endurance, or power after inactivity.
A period where adaptations regress because overload is removed.
The decay of neuromuscular and metabolic improvements without continued training.
A decrease in performance capacities following unloading or inactivity.
The process of adaptation loss caused by inadequate training frequency, volume, or intensity.
A connective tissue protein that allows tissues to stretch and recoil.
An elastic protein enabling return to original shape after deformation.
A component of connective tissue that provides elasticity rather than tensile strength.
A protein that supports tissue flexibility and resilience.
A spring-like connective tissue protein contributing to passive recoil.
A matrix protein that helps tissues regain length after stretching.
A structural protein associated with tissue compliance.
A connective tissue protein responsible for elastic properties in ligaments and other tissues.
A method for measuring muscle electrical activity.
A technique that records motor unit action potentials from muscle.
Assessment of neuromuscular activation via electrical signals in muscle tissue.
A tool used to quantify muscle activation patterns during movement.
Recording of muscle electrical activity using surface or intramuscular electrodes.
A measurement approach that reflects neural drive to muscle.
A technique to evaluate timing and amplitude of muscle activation.
A method for detecting and analyzing electrical signals produced during muscle contraction.
Cartilage rich in collagen fibers that resists compression and tension.
A tough cartilage type combining dense collagen and cartilage matrix for durability.
A load-bearing cartilage found where strong support and shock absorption are needed.
Cartilage adapted to handle both tensile and compressive stresses.
A collagen-heavy cartilage type seen in structures like intervertebral discs and menisci.
A cartilage form designed for high mechanical stress environments.
A connective tissue that provides strong cushioning under heavy loads.
A cartilage type with abundant collagen that increases strength and resistance to deformation.
Short-term overreaching that leads to performance supercompensation after recovery.
A planned, brief increase in training stress followed by rebound performance improvement.
Temporary performance decrease that resolves with rest and yields improved fitness.
A deliberate overload phase intended to produce positive adaptation after taper/recovery.
A training strategy where fatigue is accumulated briefly to stimulate later gains.
An overreaching state that is productive when paired with sufficient recovery.
A short-term imbalance (stress > recovery) that later results in enhanced performance.
A purposeful overload that initially suppresses performance but improves it after restoration.
Smooth cartilage covering joint surfaces that reduces friction.
A glassy cartilage type that provides low-friction movement at synovial joints.
Articular cartilage that helps distribute load and protect bone ends.
A cartilage form that supports and cushions joints while enabling smooth motion.
The common cartilage type forming articular surfaces and parts of the respiratory tract.
A smooth connective tissue that reduces wear between moving bones.
Cartilage providing a slick surface for joint movement and load distribution.
A cartilage type that decreases friction and absorbs compressive forces at joint interfaces.
A crystalline mineral compound that gives bone its hardness.
The calcium-phosphate mineral deposited in bone matrix to increase rigidity.
The primary inorganic mineral of bone responsible for compressive strength.
A mineral crystal that stiffens the collagen framework in bone.
Bone’s main mineral component providing hardness and resistance to compression.
A calcium phosphate crystal that contributes to bone density and strength.
The inorganic salt that mineralizes osteoid and increases bone stiffness.
A mineralized compound (calcium phosphate) that makes bone hard and load resistant.
An increase in the number of muscle fibers, with limited evidence for large effects in humans.
Growth of tissue through addition of new cells rather than enlargement of existing cells.
An increase in cell count within a tissue.
Muscle growth mechanism involving formation of additional fibers (controversial in humans).
Expansion of tissue by increasing the number of constituent cells.
A tissue adaptation where cell number rises in response to stimulus.
A cellular proliferation-based growth process (distinct from hypertrophy).
Increase in fiber number as a proposed contributor to muscle size in some contexts.
An increase in muscle fiber cross-sectional area.
Muscle growth primarily due to enlargement of existing fibers.
An adaptation where muscle cells increase size rather than number.
Increase in contractile protein content and cellular volume in muscle fibers.
A training-induced increase in muscle thickness and size.
Growth of skeletal muscle via increased myofibrillar and/or sarcoplasmic components.
An increase in the diameter of muscle fibers resulting in greater muscle size.
A size adaptation characterized by larger muscle fibers and increased CSA.
The application of force to tissues that stimulates adaptation.
External or internal forces placed on biological tissues during activity.
A physical stressor that drives remodeling in bone, tendon, and muscle.
Load exposure that signals tissues to strengthen or change structure.
The strain-producing forces that provoke musculoskeletal adaptation.
A stimulus created by weight-bearing, impact, or resistance that promotes tissue remodeling.
Forces applied to tissues that can trigger mechanotransduction responses.
A mechanical stimulus that induces structural and functional adaptation in connective tissues.
A fine fibrillar component of connective tissue contributing to structural support.
A small-diameter fiber element within the extracellular matrix.
A microscopic fibril that helps organize connective tissue architecture.
A fine structural unit that supports connective tissue integrity.
A connective tissue substructure that contributes to mechanical properties.
A small fibrillar component involved in organizing matrix proteins.
A fine fiber element that supports tissue structure and resilience.
A microscopic connective tissue fibril that participates in extracellular matrix organization.
The minimum strain magnitude required to stimulate bone adaptation.
A threshold level of mechanical strain needed to trigger bone remodeling.
The smallest effective strain stimulus that promotes osteogenic response.
A bone-loading threshold below which adaptation is minimal.
The strain level required to signal bone formation processes.
The minimum deformation stimulus that provokes bone maintenance or gain.
A concept describing the strain threshold for bone to respond to loading.
The smallest strain signal that initiates meaningful osteogenic adaptation.
A motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates.
The basic functional unit of neural control of muscle force.
One alpha motor neuron plus the muscle fibers it activates.
A neuromuscular unit that contracts together when the neuron fires.
The smallest unit of muscle activation controlled by the nervous system.
A nerve-to-muscle grouping determining force output and control precision.
A set of muscle fibers driven by a single motor neuron.
A neural control unit whose recruitment and firing rate influence muscle force.
The formation of new muscle tissue or fibers.
The developmental process of creating muscle cells and muscle fibers.
Muscle tissue generation through differentiation of precursor cells.
A process involving creation and maturation of muscle fibers.
Formation of muscle tissue, often discussed in development and regeneration contexts.
The biological process that produces new muscle cells (myocytes).
Muscle formation via cellular growth and differentiation pathways.
The creation of muscle tissue from progenitor cells into functional fibers.
The primary protein of thick filaments that generates force via cross-bridge cycling.
A contractile protein whose heads bind actin and use ATP to produce movement and force.
The thick-filament motor protein responsible for the power stroke in contraction.
A myofibrillar protein that converts chemical energy (ATP) into mechanical work.
The thick-filament protein that attaches to actin and pulls during shortening.
A motor protein with ATPase activity that drives filament sliding.
The force-producing protein whose cross-bridges interact cyclically with actin.
A thick-filament contractile protein that powers muscle contraction through ATP-dependent cycling.
The stretch reflex causing a muscle to contract in response to rapid stretching.
A protective reflex that resists sudden muscle lengthening.
A reflex mediated by muscle spindles leading to contraction after quick stretch.
The reflex arc that increases muscle activation when length changes rapidly.
A neural response to stretch that helps maintain posture and muscle tone.
An involuntary contraction triggered by muscle spindle activation during sudden stretch.
A reflex that facilitates agonist contraction and inhibits antagonist activity in response to stretch.
A rapid contraction response elicited when a muscle is quickly lengthened.
The synapse between a motor neuron and a muscle fiber.
The site where acetylcholine is released to initiate muscle fiber depolarization.
A specialized junction where neural signals are transmitted to skeletal muscle.
The connection point where motor neuron action potentials trigger muscle contraction.
A chemical synapse enabling communication from nerve to muscle.
The interface where a motor neuron activates a muscle fiber via neurotransmitter release.
The synaptic region that converts neural firing into muscle excitation.
The neuron-to-muscle synapse that initiates the excitation–contraction sequence.
Overreaching that results in prolonged performance decrements without supercompensation.
An accumulation of fatigue that reduces performance for an extended period despite recovery attempts.
A maladaptive overreaching state where performance does not rebound quickly.
A short-to-medium term training stress imbalance causing longer-lasting underperformance.
A negative outcome of excessive training load without adequate recovery, lasting weeks.
A fatigue-driven performance drop that persists and does not yield a rebound benefit.
An overreaching condition requiring extended recovery to restore baseline performance.
A state between functional overreaching and overtraining syndrome characterized by sustained decrements.
Bone-forming cells responsible for producing new bone matrix.
Cells that synthesize osteoid and promote mineral deposition.
The cells that build bone tissue during growth and remodeling.
Bone cells that lay down collagen matrix later mineralized into bone.
Matrix-producing cells essential for bone formation and repair.
Cells that contribute to increased bone mass through synthesis activity.
Bone-building cells that generate organic matrix and facilitate mineralization.
Cells that form new bone by producing osteoid and coordinating mineralization.
Mechanical loading signals that promote bone formation.
Load-related cues (strain, rate, frequency) that stimulate bone adaptation.
Stimuli that trigger bone remodeling toward increased strength or density.
Mechanical stress patterns that encourage osteoblast activity.
Bone-building signals derived from impact or resistance loading.
Loading characteristics that drive osteogenesis (bone formation).
Mechanical cues that promote bone growth and mineralization.
Signals from loading that activate pathways leading to bone formation.
A condition of low bone mass and increased fracture risk.
A skeletal disorder characterized by reduced bone strength.
Disease marked by decreased BMD and degraded bone microarchitecture.
A state where bones become more porous and fragile.
A disorder increasing risk of fractures due to weakened bone.
Low bone density and structural deterioration leading to fragility fractures.
A condition where bone resorption outpaces formation, weakening bone.
A clinical syndrome of fragile bones typically associated with aging and low BMD.
A short-term imbalance between training stress and recovery.
A temporary increase in training load that causes fatigue and performance suppression.
A period of excessive training stress relative to recovery capacity.
An overload state that may be functional or nonfunctional depending on recovery and duration.
A short-term accumulation of fatigue from training above current tolerance.
A planned or unplanned training load spike that temporarily reduces performance.
A fatigue state created by high training demands that can precede adaptation or maladaptation.
A short-duration overload that exceeds recovery and temporarily impairs performance.
A chronic maladaptive state from excessive training and insufficient recovery.
Long-term performance decline accompanied by physiological and psychological disturbances.
A persistent fatigue and underperformance condition not resolved by short rest.
A syndrome involving prolonged training stress leading to systemic dysfunction.
A chronic training-related state characterized by decreased performance and mood changes.
A long-duration maladaptation where recovery requires weeks to months.
A condition resulting from cumulative overload without adequate restoration, impairing multiple systems.
A chronic syndrome marked by sustained performance decrement and dysregulation beyond normal fatigue.
Overtraining characterized by fatigue, reduced heart rate, and performance decrements.
An OTS presentation with lowered resting HR and subdued arousal.
A chronic underperformance state associated with elevated parasympathetic tone.
Overtraining marked by lethargy, low motivation, and decreased sympathetic drive.
A form of OTS often seen in endurance athletes featuring low resting HR and fatigue.
An overtraining pattern where the body appears “shut down” rather than hyper-aroused.
OTS characterized by blunted stress responses and reduced physiological activation.
A parasympathetic-dominant overtraining state with low arousal and persistent fatigue.
The highest bone density achieved during growth and development.
Maximum lifetime bone mass typically reached in early adulthood.
The top level of BMD obtained before age-related decline begins.
The greatest amount of bone tissue accrued during maturation.
A developmental milestone representing maximal skeletal mineralization.
The maximum bone strength potential built through genetics, nutrition, and loading during youth.
The highest bone mass reached, influencing osteoporosis risk later in life.
The lifetime maximum skeletal mass achieved before maintenance/decline phases.
The angle between muscle fibers and the line of pull (tendon).
The fiber-to-tendon orientation that influences force transmission.
The oblique angle at which fibers insert into a tendon in pennate muscles.
An architectural feature affecting physiological cross-sectional area and force potential.
The angle that can increase with hypertrophy and alter force–velocity characteristics.
A muscle architecture measure describing fiber alignment relative to the tendon.
The fiber alignment angle that affects how much fiber force contributes to tendon force.
The angle between muscle fibers and the aponeurosis/tendon direction of action.
A connective tissue membrane covering the outer surface of bone (except at articular cartilage).
The fibrous outer layer of bone important for growth and repair.
A vascularized membrane that nourishes bone and supports remodeling.
The outer bone covering that anchors tendons/ligaments and aids healing.
A protective connective tissue sheath surrounding bone surfaces.
The membrane containing cells involved in bone formation and repair.
A dense connective tissue layer covering bone that contributes to appositional growth.
Bone’s outer covering that supports repair processes and attachment sites.
A precursor molecule used in collagen synthesis.
The initial collagen form produced inside cells before being processed into mature collagen.
A pre-collagen protein that is modified and secreted to form collagen fibers.
The soluble precursor that becomes collagen after enzymatic cleavage and assembly.
A collagen building block synthesized by fibroblasts prior to extracellular maturation.
The intracellular precursor that undergoes processing to produce functional collagen.
A molecule that is converted to tropocollagen and then assembled into collagen fibrils.
The early synthesis form that is later processed to create mature collagen fibers.
Gradual increase of training stress to stimulate continued adaptation.
Systematically raising load, volume, intensity, or density over time to drive gains.
A training principle requiring progressively greater stimulus as the body adapts.
Planned escalation of mechanical or metabolic demand to promote improvement.
Increasing training challenge to maintain adaptation pressure.
The concept that performance improves when stress increases beyond current capacity.
A method of applying increasing demands to prevent plateaus.
A principle where training stimulus must rise over time to keep producing adaptations.
Heart rate multiplied by systolic blood pressure, estimating cardiac workload.
An index of myocardial oxygen demand based on HR and SBP.
A cardiovascular workload metric calculated as HR × systolic BP.
A measure used to approximate how hard the heart is working during exercise.
A proxy for cardiac oxygen consumption derived from HR and blood pressure.
A workload indicator often used in clinical and exercise testing contexts.
A cardiac strain metric combining heart rate and systolic pressure.
A calculated index reflecting the heart’s work demand: HR times systolic BP.
An increase in blood flow after a period of temporary blood-flow occlusion.
The post-occlusion surge in perfusion due to accumulated metabolites and vasodilation.
A rebound increase in tissue blood flow following ischemia.
A vascular response where flow increases above baseline after restriction is released.
Increased perfusion occurring when blood supply returns after brief blockage.
A circulation response linked to metabolic byproducts and vessel dilation after occlusion.
A temporary overshoot in blood flow after removing a tourniquet or compression.
Enhanced blood flow following temporary restriction as vessels dilate and demand is repaid.
Recruitment of motor units based on force and velocity demands of a task.
Task-dependent motor unit activation patterns shaped by movement requirements.
Preferential activation of motor units depending on needed force, speed, and coordination.
The concept that recruitment strategy can differ based on exercise intent and mechanics.
Motor unit activation influenced by the demands of power, rate of force development, and load.
A pattern where the nervous system selects appropriate motor units for the task.
Recruitment behavior shaped by movement velocity and force requirements.
Choosing motor unit activation patterns that best match the mechanical and neural demands.
Motor units are recruited from smallest to largest as force demands increase.
A recruitment order rule: low-threshold units first, high-threshold units later.
The principle that slow, fatigue-resistant motor units activate before fast, powerful ones.
A motor unit recruitment hierarchy based on neuron size and threshold.
A rule explaining progressive recruitment as intensity rises.
The pattern where Type I-dominant units are recruited before Type II-dominant units.
A neural control principle linking force needs to recruitment of larger motor neurons.
A recruitment ordering concept: increasing force demand recruits progressively larger motor units.
Adaptations are specific to the type, magnitude, and direction of the applied load.
The idea that tissues adapt to the particular stresses they experience.
A principle stating training effects reflect the exact loading pattern imposed.
Load-specific remodeling: what you load is what you develop.
An adaptation rule where angle, velocity, and force direction shape the outcome.
The concept that bone, tendon, and muscle changes depend on the precise loading stimulus.
A principle explaining why different exercises produce different structural adaptations.
The notion that training adaptations match the mechanical characteristics of the overload applied.
Microfractures in bone caused by repetitive submaximal loading.
Bone injury from cumulative stress exceeding the bone’s repair capacity.
A small crack or microdamage accumulation due to repeated impact or load.
A fatigue-related bone injury resulting from overuse.
Microdamage that progresses when remodeling cannot keep pace with loading.
A repetitive-load bone injury commonly seen with running, jumping, or high volume training.
A fracture developing gradually from repeated strain rather than a single traumatic event.
Bone microinjury caused by chronic repetitive stress and insufficient recovery.
Multi-joint exercises that load the spine and large muscle groups.
Compound movements that impose significant axial loading and whole-body demand.
Exercises like squats/deadlifts/presses that stress multiple joints and major muscle mass.
Large-scale lifts that produce high systemic training stress and require trunk stabilization.
Primary multi-joint lifts that create strong mechanical loading for adaptation.
Exercises characterized by heavy loading and major skeletal support involvement.
Compound lifts that typically require bracing and stabilize the spine under load.
Multi-joint movements that heavily load the body and drive broad neuromuscular adaptation.
Overtraining characterized by elevated resting heart rate and heightened arousal.
An OTS presentation featuring increased sympathetic activity and irritability.
A chronic underperformance state marked by hyperexcitability and elevated stress markers.
Overtraining with signs like insomnia, restlessness, and increased resting HR.
A sympathetic-dominant overtraining pattern often linked to high-intensity stress exposure.
OTS characterized by elevated catecholamine-like responses and increased arousal.
An overtraining state where the system appears chronically “revved up.”
Overtraining marked by increased resting HR, agitation, and persistent performance decline.
A collection of signs and symptoms that occur together.
A consistent cluster of clinical features associated with a condition.
A set of symptoms that tend to co-occur and indicate a particular disorder.
A grouped pattern of findings rather than a single isolated symptom.
A recognizable combination of signs used to characterize a condition.
A diagnostic grouping based on repeated symptom patterns.
Multiple related symptoms that collectively define a condition.
A pattern of associated signs and symptoms forming a clinical picture.
A tendon’s resistance to deformation under load.
The amount a tendon stretches for a given applied force (inverse of compliance).
A mechanical property describing how much a tendon elongates when loaded.
Higher stiffness means less stretch at the same force.
A characteristic affecting force transmission and rate of force development.
A connective tissue property influenced by collagen content and cross-linking.
A measure of tendon rigidity that impacts elastic energy storage and return.
The mechanical resistance of tendon tissue to length change during loading.
A giant elastic protein contributing to passive muscle tension.
A sarcomere protein acting like a spring between Z-line and thick filament.
A structural protein that stabilizes the myosin filament and provides elasticity.
A protein responsible for recoil and passive resistance during muscle stretch.
A key contributor to passive stiffness and sarcomere alignment.
The elastic filament that helps muscles return to resting length after stretch.
A large protein that maintains sarcomere integrity and generates passive tension.
A spring-like sarcomeric protein that supports structure and passive force.
Spongy inner bone with high metabolic activity.
Porous bone tissue arranged in a lattice that adapts quickly to loading changes.
The inner bone structure that helps dissipate forces and supports marrow.
Bone with higher surface area and faster remodeling compared to cortical bone.
A lattice-like bone tissue that contributes to shock absorption and load distribution.
The metabolically active bone type found in vertebrae and ends of long bones.
A porous bone architecture that is highly responsive to mechanical stimuli.
Spongy bone tissue that remodels rapidly and supports compressive load distribution.
The ratio of ventilation to oxygen uptake or carbon dioxide production.
A measure of how much air is ventilated per unit of O2 consumed (VE/VO2) or CO2 produced (VE/VCO2).
An index of ventilatory efficiency during exercise testing.
A respiratory ratio reflecting ventilation demand relative to metabolic gas exchange.
A metric used to identify ventilatory thresholds and inefficiency.
The amount of minute ventilation required for a given VO2 or VCO2.
A measure of breathing efficiency; higher values typically indicate less efficient ventilation.
A cardiopulmonary exercise variable expressing VE relative to VO2 or VCO2.
